questions.text: 1. An outbreak of Zika virus infection was reported by the WHO. Which of the following is not a mode of transmission of this virus?
questions.solution:
Zika virus is not transmitted through respiratory droplets.

Zika virus (RNA virus) is a flavivirus transmitted primarily by infected mosquitoes of the Aedes genus, mainly the Aedes aegypti.

Other modes of transmission include 

* Materno-fetal or intrauterine transmission

* Sexual intercourse, due to the exchange of body fluids

* Blood/blood products transfusion

* Organ transplantation is also a potential mode of transmission of Zika virus

The majority of the people infected with this virus are asymptomatic. Few develop mild symptoms like fever, conjunctivitis, rash, myalgia, arthralgia, malaise, and headache. It has been reported to trigger Guillain-Barre syndrome, myelitis, and encephalitis in older children and adults.

Zika virus infection during pregnancy is known to cause congenital Zika syndrome, a condition characterized by severe defects in the newborn, including microcephaly. The image below shows various modes of transmission of the Zika virus.



There is no specific treatment available for this disease. Adequate hydration and rest are advised, along with analgesics and antipyretics for pain and fever.

questions.text:
3. Identify the correct sequence of steps in HIV replication.
* Integration of viral DNA
* Translation
* Cleavage of polyproteins
* Reverse transcription
* Transcription
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of steps in HIV replication is 4→1→5→2→3.

* Reverse transcription

* Integration of viral DNA

* Transcription

* Translation

* Cleavage of polyproteins

The human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) virus is a spherical, enveloped RNA virus. The nucleocapsid has an icosahedral shell and a cone-shaped core, enclosing the ribonucleoproteins. The genome comprises two identical single-stranded, RNA copies, with the reverse transcriptase enzyme, which is a characteristic feature of retroviruses.

The image below shows the structure of HIV:



Replication process: The viral reverse transcriptase (RNA-directed DNA polymerase) enzyme uses the viral RNA genome to synthesize viral DNA. This DNA (provirus) is integrated into the host cell chromosome by integrase. Transcription occurs to create new viral RNA. RNA undergoes translation to make viral proteins. The viral protease cleaves new polyproteins to create a mature infectious virus.

questions.text: 4. Bollinger inclusion bodies are seen in which of the following infections?
questions.solution:
Bollinger inclusion bodies are seen in fowlpox. 

Inclusion bodies are the most characteristic histological features seen in virus-infected cells. Inclusion bodies can be demonstrated under a light microscope. 

Inclusion bodies can be situated in the:

* Cytoplasm as in poxviruses, rabies. 

* Nucleus as in herpesviruses

* Both cytoplasm and nucleus as in measles virus

Inclusion bodies are generally acidophilic and appear as pink structures when stained with Giemsa stain or eosin methylene blue but some viruses like adenovirus have basophilic inclusions. 

Other options:

Option A: In measles, infected cells show acidophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions. The lymphoid tissues of measles patients show multinucleated giant cells named Warthin-Finkeldey cells. 

Option C: Vaccinia infected cells have small multiple inclusion bodies named Guarnieri bodies. 

Option D: In rabies infected brain cells, intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions named Negri bodies are seen.

questions.text: 5. A 78-year-old male patient presented with meningoencephalitis. Laboratory workup for Herpes Simplex is negative. An increased rate of deaths in crows in the neighborhood has been reported. You suspect an arbovirus whose life cycle is shown below. It can be classified under which of the following family?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is suggestive of West Nile encephalitis caused by the West Nile Virus belonging to the family Flaviviridae. Other important species under the genus flavivirus include:

* Dengue virus

* Japanese encephalitis virus

* Yellow fever virus

West Nile Virus is a common viral febrile illness and is the most common cause of arboviral encephalitis in the United States. It is also seen in The Middle East, Europe, Africa, and Asia. In India, it is found in regions of Rajasthan to Karnataka.

The virus has a predominantly enzootic lifecycle involving birds and mosquitos, mostly belonging to the Culex species such as C. pipiens (although Aedes and Anopheles might also be rarely involved). Humans and other mammals such as horses are incidentally involved in the cycle. Very rarely, the virus may be transmitted through organ transplantation and blood transfusion. 

Clinically, the majority of the West Nile Virus infections are asymptomatic. Symptomatic patients present with fever, maculopapular rash, lymphadenopathy, myalgia, arthralgia, headache, and fatigue. The elderly, ill, and immunocompromised individuals may be affected more severely than the general population. They may develop neurological manifestations such as tremors, acute flaccid paralysis resembling polio, aseptic meningitis, and diffuse encephalitis. Very rarely, patients may develop features of transient parkinsonism. 

Note:

Arbovirus is a term used to refer to any viruses that are transmitted by arthropod vectors. There is no family or order by the name arbovirus. The word arbovirus is an acronym (Arthropod-Borne virus). Arboviruses are classified into families named Togaviridae, Flaviviridae, Bunyaviridae, Reoviridae, Arenaviridae and Filoviridae.

questions.text: 7. A patient presented with a high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity, and seizures. The life cycle of the causative organism is given below. Which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.solution:
The given clinical history of high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity, and seizures, along with the given replication cycle showing a virus with a linear double-stranded DNA genome, is suggestive of HSV Encephalitis caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV). HSV-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR is the investigation of choice for HSV encephalitis. 

Steps of HSV replication:

The virus enters the cell by fusing with the plasma membrane, and viral DNA is released from the capsid at the nuclear pore. This is followed by the circularization of the genome and transcription of immediate-early genes.

α-Proteins are products of immediate-early genes. These proteins stimulate the transcription of early genes. β-proteins are products of early genes. These proteins function in DNA replication, to yield concatemeric DNA. Transcription of late genes gives rise to γ-proteins. These primarily consist of viral structural proteins and participate in virion assembly.

Viral DNA is cleaved from concatemers and then packaged into capsids. Enveloped viral particles collect in the endoplasmic reticulum and are then transported by a vesicular movement to the cell surface.

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis is defined as inflammation of brain parenchyma caused by the herpes virus, and it typically presents as an acute febrile illness. Patients typically present with acute onset of fever, altered levels of consciousness, personality changes, and evidence of either focal or diffuse neurologic signs and symptoms, especially in the temporal lobe. Focal or generalized seizures occur in many patients with HSV encephalitis. Other most commonly encountered focal findings include aphasia, ataxia, upper motor neuron or lower motor neuron type lesions, and cranial nerve deficits.

HSV-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR is the investigation of choice for HSV encephalitis. Other investigations that can help include CSF examination, CSF culture, serological studies, MRI, CT, EEG, and brain biopsy. The T2-weighted MRI of the brain will show hyperintensity in the temporal lobe in most of the patients. Bilateral involvement of the temporal lobe is more common in HSV encephalitis.

Management includes supportive therapy (monitoring of intracranial pressure, fluid restriction, avoidance of hypotonic IV fluids), anticonvulsants for seizures, and intravenous acyclovir is beneficial in treating HSV encephalitis.

Other options:

Option A: CSF culture in chick embryos - It is not a sensitive test used for the diagnosis of HSV encephalitis. Negative CSF viral cultures have no value in ruling out HSV encephalitis. Although this method can be used to isolate HSV, it is not as sensitive or specific as PCR for viral DNA and it can take a longer time to obtain results. 

Option B: Tzanck smear of CSF - A positive smear shows multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and ground glass appearance. It is a rapid, inexpensive, and fairly sensitive diagnostic test. The Tzanck smear is typically used to diagnose cutaneous herpes infections, such as herpes simplex or varicella-zoster virus. It is not an appropriate diagnostic test for HSV encephalitis, as it does not provide definitive confirmation of the presence of HSV in the CSF.

Option D: Brain biopsy was used earlier to establish a diagnosis and begin early specific therapy, but now has been replaced by HSV DNA detection by CSF PCR.

questions.text: 8. A patient presents with complaints of fever, cough, and nasal discharge. He was diagnosed with infection by the influenza virus, which is an enveloped virus. Which of the following is false regarding enveloped viruses?
questions.solution:
The lipid of enveloped viruses is largely of host-cell origin, whereas protein is virus coded.

Being enveloped contributes to their lipid solvent susceptibility. This is the reason alcohol-based hand sanitizers and soaps are used. The lipid membrane dissolution and protein denaturation by ethanol lead to membrane disruption and inhibition of metabolism.

Properties of enveloped virus:

* The envelope confers chemical, antigenic, and biological properties on the virus.

* It is made of lipid (phospholipid) and protein (glycoprotein).

* Lipid is largely of host cell origin, whereas glycoprotein is virus coded.

* The lipid is acquired when the viral nucleocapsid buds through a cellular membrane during maturation. Budding occurs only at sites where virus-specific proteins have been inserted into the host cell membrane.

* Protein subunits may be seen projecting on the surface of envelope called peplomer, e.g, hemagglutinin and neuraminidase of influenza virus.

questions.text: 9. You are informed that the country’s security agency suspects bioterrorism as there was a sudden surge in patients presenting with fever, severe headache, vomiting followed by convulsions, and altered sensorium. The transmission cycle of the likely causative agent is given below. To which bioterrorism category does it belong?
questions.solution:
The given history and the above image depicts the transmission cycle of the Nipah virus. It belongs to category C bioterrorism

Nipah virus is a zoonotic RNA virus that shows both animal-to-human (bats, pigs) and human-to-human transmission. The natural hosts are fruit bats.

Transmission:

* During the 1999 outbreak among pig farmers in Malaysia, the transmission was from direct contact with sick pigs, or exposure to secretions from the pigs, or contact with the contaminated tissues of pigs.

* In subsequent outbreaks (in 2001) in Bangladesh and India, the consumption of fruits or fruit products((such as raw date palm juice) contaminated with urine or saliva from infected fruit bats was the most likely source of infection.

* Human-to-human transmission through close contact with people's secretions and excretions has also been reported.

Infected people present with fever, headaches, myalgia, vomiting, sore throat followed by dizziness, drowsiness, altered consciousness, and neurological signs that indicate encephalitis.

Bioterrorism is the deliberate release of an agent by attackers that causes one or more of a variety of different diseases.

The agents of bioterrorism are classified into 3 categories:

Category A bioterrorism agents are those which are easily transmitted from one person to the other and are associated with high mortality rates and thus have the potential to cause major public health impacts. Examples include Bacillus anthracis, Clostridium botulinum and Yersinia pestis.

Category B bioterrorism agents are those which are moderately easy to disseminate and are associated with moderate morbidity and low mortality rates. Examples include Coxiella burnetti and Brucella.

Category C bioterrorism agents are those which are emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination in the future due to ease of availability, high mortality and morbidity rates, and ease of production and dissemination. Examples include Nipah and Hanta viruses.

questions.text: 10. Which of the following are glycoprotein projections found on the surface of the virus?
questions.solution:
The peplomers are glycoprotein projections found on the surface of the viral envelope.

Structure of a virus has the following:

* Nucleocapsid: The capsid with enclosed nucleic acid is known as Nucleocapsid.

* Envelope: A lipid-containing membrane that surrounds some virus particles. It is acquired during viral maturation by a budding process through a cellular membrane.

* Tegument: Proteinaceous structure present between the envelope and capsid.

Note: Coronaviruses are a group of spherical or pleomorphic enveloped RNA viruses having club or petal-shaped peplomers. Coronaviruses are named for the crown-like spikes on their surface.

* Bunyavirus

questions.text: 12. Which of the following options represents the Australia antigen in the given image of viral structure?
questions.solution:
The Australia antigen, which is another name for hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg), is marked as '1' in the given image. This antigen was first isolated from the serum of an Australian person, hence the name Australia antigen.

Under electron microscopy, the serum from hepatitis B patients shows three types of particles:

* Spherical particle: 22 nm; most abundant; containing only HBsAg

* Filamentous or tubular particle: 22 nm; containing only HBsAg

* Double-walled spherical structure: 42 nm diameter; the complete hepatitis B virus; called the Dane particle, since it was first described by Dane

The illustration given below shows the sphericle structure of the hepatitis B virus.



Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) is an objective marker of active HBV infection and is detectable in large quantities in the serum. It is present in active infection and also may be present in the chronic carrier state (when it persists for longer than 6 months). 

Hepatitis B core antigen (HBcAg) is a capsid/core protein found on nucleocapsid. 

Hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg) is the envelop antigen. It is a protein on the nucleocapsid. It is a marker of active viral replication. The persistence of HBeAg is an indicator of chronic hepatitis B with active viral replication. Anti-HBeAg antibodies are produced against these antigens.

The nucleocapsid contains the DNA, which appears partially double-stranded and partially single-stranded. It is associated with a viral DNA polymerase that has both DNA-dependent DNA polymerase and RNA-dependent reverse transcriptase functions.

The image given below shows the hepatitis B virus genome.

questions.text: 13. All of the following viruses replicate in the nucleus, except:
questions.solution:
Picornaviruses replicate in the cytoplasm, not in the nucleus. 

They are single-stranded RNA viruses that have icosahedral symmetry.

questions.text: 14. Which of the following is the cellular receptor for the RNA virus shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image showing a bullet-shaped virus, with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA is characteristic of rabies viruses belonging to the family Rhabdoviridae. The cellular receptor for the rabies virus is the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor.

Rabies is a fatal infection of the central nervous system transmitted by the bite of a rabid animal. It is caused by rhabdoviruses. These viruses are enveloped, rod or bullet shaped and contain single-stranded RNA. This virus attaches to the cells via its glycoprotein spikes and the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor acts as the cellular receptor.



Other options:

Option A: CR2 or CD21 is the receptor for the C3d component of complement. It also acts as the viral receptor for EBV.

Option C: CD4 is expressed on macrophages and T lymphocytes are the viral receptor for HIV. Chemokine receptors CXCR4 and CCR5 act as coreceptors.

Option D: SARS-CoV-2 enters the host cell via the ACE2 receptor.

questions.text: 15. Which of the following viruses belongs to the family filoviridae, and is transmitted as depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ebola virus belongs to the family filoviridae and is transmitted by bats.

Ebola virus:

* It is the cause of an emerging disease called Ebola virus disease and is widespread in Africa.

* It belongs to the Filoviridae family.

* Incubation period: 2 to 21 days.

* Transmission is through contact with infectious bodily fluids or organs of animals like chimpanzees and monkeys.

* Human to human transmission is through blood or body fluids of an infected symptomatic person.

* It can remain in semen for up to 3 months, although sexual transmission has not been reported yet.

* Symptoms include fever, intense weakness, vomiting, diarrhea, rashes, and, in extreme cases, internal and external bleeding.

* Ebola virus shows a bowl of spaghetti appearance.

* The current treatment is mainly supportive.

* Patients are susceptible to reinfection even after complete cure.

questions.text: 16. A 35-year-old wildlife photographer presents with sudden onset of fever, headache, and myalgia. On examination, you notice gingival bleeding and conjunctival hemorrhages. He recently visited a forest in Karnataka that has a large population of monkeys. What are the amplifier hosts, reservoirs, and incidental hosts respectively for this disease?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with exposure to monkeys, fever, myalgia, headache, conjunctival hemorrhage and gingival bleeds is suggestive of Kyasanur forest disease (KFD). Monkeys are amplifier hosts, rodents are reservoirs and humans are incidental hosts.

Kyasanur forest disease is an arboviral infection caused by a member of the virus family Flaviviridae. It is transmitted by ticks (Haemaphysalis spinigera) and is endemic to the forests of Karnataka and Kerala.

The clinical features include:

* Fever

* Headache

* Conjunctivitis

* Myalgia 

* Meningoencephalitis

* Hemorrhagic symptoms- hemorrhages in skin, mucosa and gastrointestinal bleeds.

The diagnosis is established via PCR, virus isolation from blood, or enzyme-linked immunosorbent serologic assay. A killed KFD virus vaccine was used in a small field trial and appeared to provide some degree of protection.

questions.text: 17. A 10-year-old boy presents with the passage of blood-colored urine, pain during micturition, and increased frequency of urination for the last 2 days. After further investigations, he is diagnosed with acute hemorrhagic cystitis caused by adenovirus. Which of the following characteristics correctly describes this causative agent?
questions.solution:
This is a case of acute hemorrhagic cystitis, which is caused by adenovirus—a naked double-stranded DNA virus. 

Acute hemorrhagic cystitis is a viral urinary tract infection. It presents with cystitis and gross hematuria. 

Adenovirus types 7, 11, 34, and 35 are the common serotypes associated with this disease and can be recovered from the blood and urine of patients with hemorrhagic cystitis. 

Other illnesses caused by adenoviruses include

* Respiratory tract - Tonsillitis, pharyngitis, pneumonia

* Eyes - Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis, acute follicular conjunctivitis

* Gastrointestinal tract - Acute viral gastroenteritis 

* Urinary tract - Acute hemorrhagic cystitis

questions.text: 18. What is the true statement regarding the phenomenon depicted in the image below?

choices.text: Seen in influenza B and C

questions.solution:
The given image depicts an antigenic shift, which results in a pandemic.

Antigenic variation in the influenza virus is of 2 types: antigenic shift and antigenic drift.

Antigenic shift is a major and drastic change caused by genetic reassortment between human, swine, and avian influenza viruses, which results in the emergence of a new subtype of virus. It is seen in influenza A virus and absent in B and C as only a few related viruses are present in animals. It is a unique property of influenza virus because of its segmented genome.

Antigenic drift is a gradual change caused by the accumulation of point mutation in protein-encoding genes. All 3 types of influenza virus exhibit the antigenic drift. Antigenic shift | Antigenic drift Occur in type A | Occurs in type A and to less extent in type B Results in pandemic and major epidemics | Results in periodic epidemic and sporadic cases Due to genetic reassortment | Due to point mutation Occurs every 20-30 years | Occurs every 2-3 years

questions.text: 20. Identify the virus in the transmission cycle shown in the given image:
questions.solution:
The transmission cycle of the Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus is shown in the image. 

Japanese encephalitis follows bird-arthropod-human transmission. Humans are the dead-end hosts, pigs are the amplifier hosts, and herons act as reservoir hosts. The disease is transmitted by the bite of Culex mosquitoes, specifically Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India)

Clinical features include high fever, headache, and vomiting. Signs of encephalitis such as convulsions, neck rigidity, and altered sensorium appear after 1-6 days. Measures like mosquito control, and locating piggeries away from houses can be done.

Inactivated vero cell culture-derived SA-14-14-2 vaccine is approved for use in India. JE vaccine is given in two doses- at 9-12 months of age and at 16-24 months of age in areas that are endemic to the disease, according to the National Immunization Schedule. 

Other options:

Option-A: Nipah virus is a zoonotic virus, which is transmitted from pigs to humans. Fruit bats are the natural hosts. It causes severe encephalitis with high mortality.

Option B: Ebola virus belongs to the family Filoviridae and is transmitted by bats. Human-to-human transmission through blood or body fluids can occur. It causes fever, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and hemorrhage. 

The image below shows the lifecycle of the ebola virus:



Option D: Zika virus is transmitted to human beings by the bite of an infected Aedes mosquito. It can also be transmitted trans-placentally, causing microcephaly and other severe fetal brain defects.
